data: G.V. Gentili, «Nuovi elementi di epigrafia siracusana», Archivio Storico Siracusano 7 (1961): 5–25
Base recording construction by a C. Roscius and a Sextia
Four lines of Latin letters, steadily decreasing in height, with lines 1 and 3 set to the left margin, and lines 2 and 4 indented by one letter.

Elegantly carved letters in a fine v-cut, simple serifs, and a broad / square module (O, C, M all very wide), R with an elegant extended tail, P open, M with four full length strokes all off vertical.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2018-03-15

Three lines of large Greek letters; all are incomplete, but the unjustified left margin suggests a text that was originally centred on the stone

Thinly incised broad letters of regular height, without serifs or marked terminations to the strokes. Alpha has straight bar; Beta has closed loops, in the second instance separated from one another. Sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, the mid-strokes meeting slightly over halfway across.
Letters of the 3rd century BCE; the apparent double kingship reference suggests the Hieronian period

4[Συρακόσιοι]
Large letters centrally placed on the stone in a single line. The text is incomplete at start and finish.

Regularly spaced letters of even height, neatly cut (a broad v-cut) with minimal terminations to the strokes. Alpha has straight bar; Kappa has short arms, centrally placed; Omicron is very small (105 mm) and midline; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes.
